 RESOLVED, By the House ef Representations, That the following be proposed as amendments to the Con- sttution of this State. which, when approvedsand a. dopted in the manner by the Constitution prescribed, shato all ntents and purposes, become part thereof

 Art. lst, From and after the first Wednesday of red and thirty, the Senate of this State shall consist of no less than eighteen no more than twenty-four members, to be chosen by Districts.

 Art. 2d The General Assembly which shall be hol- den on the hast Wednesday of May, in the year one the State into districts for the choice of Senator's and shall determine what number shall be elected in each which districts shall not be less than eight more than tweuty-our in number, and shall always be com- posed of contiguous territory, and in forming them no town shall be divided shall the whole Or part of one county be joined to the whole or part of another county, to form district; regard being had to the population in said apportionment and in forming said districts in such manner that county shall have less than two Senators. The districts, when established, shall continue the until the session of the Gem eral Assembly next after the completion of the next cencns of the United States; which said Assembly shall have power to alter the same, if found necessary preserve proper equality between said districts in respect to the number of inhabitants theren accord

 ing to the principles above recited; after which said

 

 tors altered, except any session of the General As. sembly next after the completion of census of the United States and then only according to the princ. pies above described. VI #essT1 AIM s5

Sd At the meeting of Electors on the first Mon day of April, in the year one thousand eight hundred and thirty, and annually thereafter immediately after the choice of Representatives the Electors qualified by law to vote in the choice of such Representatives shall be called upon, by the presiding officer in sucL meeting, in the several towns within their districts spectivey bring in their ballots for such person or

 number of persons, to be Senator Senators for suc Districts in the next General Assembly, as shall by law be allowed to such Districts respectively: which person or persons, the time of holding such meet. ngs shall belong to- and reside in the respective Die. tric,s in which they shall be so balloed for as afcre- saidAnd each Elector present at such meeting qua- flied aforesaid may thereupon bring in his ballot or suffrage for such person persons he shall choose be Senators for such Districts, not exceeding the number by law allowed to the same, with the name names of such person persons faisy written on one piece of paper.And the votes so given in shalt be received counted, canyassed and declared in the same manner provided by the Constitution for the choice ofsenatcrs-T The person or persons (nct ex- ceedng the number by law allowed to the Districts in which such vote shall be given in) having the highest number Of y0es shall be declared to be duly elected for such Dstric.s-But in the event of equality of votes between two or more of the persons voted tors vidcd for by the Committe, designate which of such persons shall be declared to hs duly elected.  CHriosities o Kep.--At Kew, there is neither doc tor lawyer, nor barber; the postmaster, it is said, neither read write and it IS vcarage with out vicar, he having made himself conspicuous at Thurtes trial has ever since been absent; yet there is no lack of Sermons, for the Inkeepers bear ing that name, and his brother, butcher, have each a large family ..

 Extraordinary Weather.---The thermometer which, Thursday and Friday last, ranging from so to 84 gradually sunk down to 60 on Friday night, after a thunder gust and heavy fall ofrain. We experienced on Saturday morning such an Atmosphere as usually accompanies September dawn, the wind East and North, and varying once twice to the West. It is still very cool and we find warm covering very agree able.--1 Charleston Paper, June 25.1

NOTICE.

MR. EDrToR---Fate has so ordered it. together with my own folly that should belong to that much scof fed at and think I can truly and understndingly say from experience, miserable class of bipeds, ycleped "Old Bachelors.'' Now I should like to trouble the younger part of your readers with few words upon this subject. I shall not tire their pa- tience with long recital of the kicks and cuffs which have received, nor the mseries which have endl- red in consequence of remaining in "state of sim gle blesseduess, as it is called. When was young although Twas souckya chap toinitiae myself into the goodgraces of the ladies' took for my text

 It's not good for man take himself wife,, and many is the good practical discourse which, have preached therefrom, to my young companions-tho' not with remarkably good success. But stuck per tinaciously and obsnatey to it, albe until subse- quenty began to think that my preaching had para

 Tel in that ofa certain pious monk, whogpreached long sermon against stealing and its pernicons and mischevous effects, while at the same time he had pudding in his sleeve which he had obtained by theft

 would inform them at the present time, that have experienced good deal of misery sitting and lisen- ing the " solitary sghings my tea-ketle" long as have done ---and thai Ihave no notion of making virtue of necessity in extolling the happiness of a bachelors lfeit is but of dogs life the best ---and would recommend to every one to Keep clear of it. the wise and cogent arguments of Peter Single to the contrary notwithstanding. To tell the plain truth, although the miseres have euudergone moi quite equal those of the fabed Tyus. who is rep- resented in Eneas' descent into Hades, as having a ravenous vuture digging into his side and devouring his iver which grows fast enough to satisfy the yora- cious appetite of the bird yet they of ordinary nature. isan erroneous opinion which some young people have, of the danger of being wrecked upon the shoals of matrimony, ifthey sail that cruise ;but they may rest assured the authority of one whose knowledge has been dervedfom experience, ,thatthey will eventually sink in the qucksands and ouagmires of single bessedness, fthes travel that road. Let some your young readers, who halting between opinions just fancy to themselves an oldsuperan- nuated bachelor, the very picture of loneliness like myself for nstance sitting in his corner with pair ofspectacles athwart his asaprotuberance, poringo verthe pages of" The Bachelor" (which you maybe assured does not afford him much consolatio---or s- tening the aforementioned music of the tea-kettle ruminating on by-gone days and come to their own couclusions. Although never expect to tako to my self ri6, being too old to think of such step now earnestly advise all my brother bachelors each to obtain for himself cae sponsa as soon as may be.-- And would advise the young men, in the favourite language of Peter Single, to avoid being a bache lor" avoid it as you would the devil.''

The frss Ecrlesias.ioal Church and Society in this town have, with the most perfect unanimity, voted CaltO Rev. Daniel L. Carol, of Aeghany Co. Penn. late of the Theological Seminary, PrincesOn, N. T. become their spiritual teacher and guide, in the gOs pei ministry. The perfect harmony which prevailed in the Church aud Society in voting this invitation, and in offering support of $IOOO per annun, induces hope that Mir. c. will accept the call, and soon be settled among

 The Students of the Law Office, in this village, eel ebrated the fy-frst anniversary of American Inde- pendence, by appropriate exercises in St. Michaels Church, and public dinner. The address by Mir. Parker heard with interest and pleasure by all in the house. His few remarks inrelaon to present na- tional poltcswere such might have been expected from liberal and enlightened mind He made no aIuson to either of the candidates for the next Pres dency, personality but simply spoke of the principle So much agtated at the present day relative to state rights, and the Pretended encroachment upon these rights by the General Government; and showed most conclusiveIy that as nation, we have more to fear from the independent sovereignty of the individual states, than we have fromany liability encreachment

  ernment. This question is afavorite hobby with the opposition, who continually clamouring for the independence of the separate states and pretending lest this independence should be destroyed by the present administration. We care however, much inclined believe in the vulgar proverb that if the states are all claim the independence that Geor gia has recently claimed, there is much more danger that the "pigs will eat the sow, than there is that the SOW will eat up the pigs"

 After the close of the services at the Church, pro- cession was formed by the Students, accompanied by several respectable gentlemen of the village, which moved to the County House, where dinner was ser- we'd up; after partaking of which the following toasts were drank:-

 1. The Day we ceebrate-Glorious as the natal of Our country--great in the annals of Freedomlong 1t continue to be celebrated Jubilee by her sous. -3 cheers

 2. Our Country-The chosen home ofthe free-the refuge of the oppressed-May day arrive when the cank of saverys chain shall be no longer heard and her foot not find resting place upon our so--- s cheers.

 3. The Constitution of the United States-Wisdom and Prudence presided at its formaton--may it's de- crees be enforced with Justice and moderation ---3 cheers. .

 4. The memory ofWashington.- Drank 6a silence.

 ,. The President of the United States & Heads of Departments.---3 Cheers. g4y

 6. Tho Governor of Connecticut.-.-3Cheers

 '. The late Governor of Connecticut the eve- ming of his life be calm its morn was brilliant ---6 Cheers. 8. The surviving Heroes of the Revolution----the few remaining monuments of glorious age--to them are we indebted for the rich inheritance enjoy and sooB may the Justice of an enfarehised people smoothe their passage to the grave, by rescung them from the cold embrace of Penury.--6 Cheers

 9. The Army---In the hour of danger and of peril it has noby discharged its duty, in peace let us cherish it.---3 Cheers #

 10. The Navy---In War our bulwark, in Peace our pride----nay its glory increase with its strength--3 Cheers.

 II. Charles Carroll-.--Tbe sole surviving signer of that instrument which pucked the brightest gem from Brtans glitterng coronal and gave existence na- ton ;brliany shone his rising gloriousy beam his setting sun.--6 Cheers

 12. Our Liberty---An ollodidl eState won by the sword, and held by in fee simple, may descend to prosteriy free from rack rent, and unncumbered by burdensome mortguges.---6 Cheers.

 l3. The Fair

 What despots in the battle field

 Have tried to do in van---

 To make the free unto them yield

 And wear a chain-

 The far--.the cruel fair have done

 They've done it by their winsome wiles

 What arms could not, their witchery,s won--

 What magic's In their smiles.-.- Cheers.

 IA number of volunteer Toasts were drank but we are obliged to omit them for want of room.l

 On the Eth ult. very large and respectable meeting of wool growers manufacturers and others interested in the promotion of American industry, convened at Rutland Vt. for the purpose of considering the expe- diency of Appointing delegatesto the Haisburgh Con- vention. Many able addresses were made to the meet ing in support of sundry resolutions approving the pursued by the great and patriotic state of Pennsylvania, in calling convention at this time, in order to take firm and enlightened stand in favor of the American System. Mr. Mallary, the able chairman of the Committee Manufactures, in the last Con- gress, addressed the meeting, and urged the import ance of the appointment of delegates to the Penn. meeting, for the purpose of refutng in the clearest manner the oft repeated assertion upon the floor of Congress, that the American farmer has no interest in the protection of manufactures, and is totally inder- ent to the success of the Woollens Bl-the measure having originated entirely in the avarice of rich cap- taists. Theremarks of Mir. M. in support of the ap- Pointment ofdelegates from Vt. will apply with equal force to Connecticut But we presume few if any of agricultural readers require argumentsto to convince them of the importance of protecting and encouraging domestic industry. At the above meeting the follow ing gentlemen were appointed delegates to the Harris hurgh Convention: Wm. Jarvis Esq. Hon. R. c. Malary, Hon. Elijah Paine, Wm. Hall, Esq. and Hon. Heman Allen.

 About Seventy delegates assembled ai HarrishuEgh Pa. on the e7th ult from the different counties in tai state, for the purpose of appointing delegates to the General Convention which is to meet at that place on the Both inst consider the present state of our wool growing .aDd wool manufacturing interest, and such other manufactures require encouragement. The following the organization of the meeting, and IS also list of the delegates to the general convention. ConrentiOa at Hnrisburg---Judge Burnside was President and Jas. $. Graft, Secretary. The follow ing is a correct list of the Delegates appointed in the general convention; Hon. John Todd of Bedford, Charles Ingersoll, of Philadelphia, Matthew Carey, of Philadelphia, Hon. Charles Huston, of Centre, Hon. Waiter Forward, of Pittsburg, Hon. Jonathan Roberts, of Montgomery, Joseph Patterson, Esq. of Pittsburg, Hon. Joseph Ritner, of Washington, Jas Todd, of Fayere, Wm. Clark, of Cauphin, David Townsend, of Chester, Samuel Baird, of Berks, Wm P. Macay, of Miflin Alexander Reed of Washing ton, Daniel Montgomery, ofColumbia. and Geo. Den- nisOn of Luzerne. "aa

 Public opinion is fast developing itself. From the Eastfrom the West, and from the North, the news IS most cheering. The violent hostility of the leaders of the opposition to Domestic industry protected by the Wooen B--the defeat of the hundred and SSrty thOusGd dOlLGrS interest saving bilthe violent and indscrminate opposition to the Administration, right wrong, and the bitter personal denunciaon of the i members of the Government who have grown old in the faithful performances of public servce are, bihed producing strong reaetlon and the People are railyng with firm and cheerful spirit in defence of the Government of their country.--- VttGge Record. The Duke of Wellington acknowledged in the House of Lords that it would be ridiculous in him to think himself qualified to act Prime Minister of England, thongh he thought himself qualified to com mand her armies. Modesty seems to have deserted republics, and taken refuge in courts Such senti- l T.aI him mmorta--but he seems better disposed to act on 1 the maxim, "to keep what he gets and get what he can''-[ Rich. Whg.1

 The following paragraph is copied from the Mon 1 treal Courant of Wednesday last;

 "The Hon. Col. J. Ramsay, brother of His Excel lency the Governor in Chief has lately arrived with despatches to His Excellency from England. We un- derstand that immediately upon his reaching the Gov ernor messenger was sent to summon the attendance of the Socito~ General, and the whole party to 1 proceed forthwith to Quebec, to examine the de- spatches. It Is rumored, but we give it only that the despaches contain instructions of HiSEx. to take away the constitution hitherto enjoyed by the country and to place 1t under the control of the Gov ernor and Council; which measure, 1t is said, was occasioned by the difficulties which constantly distract the Provincial Parliament. It is not very probable that this report correct for the constitution was ] granted to this country by act of Parliament we presume it could onysbe taken away by one, unless 1 there was provision in the act by which 1t was | try it might be taken away. Certain it is that the | despatches contain something of importance to the country, and probably will put rest to the exist ing difficulties, which we should not regret. It is certain that strong military force is coming out to this country, for what purpose we cannot dvine." Military naoremepts.--The embarkation of British troops for Canada, the enrolment and discipline of the provincial militia, and the extensive fortifcations now going forward wears an appearance of hostile preparations, according better with times that have l passed than the amcable relations which now ex- ist between England and America. We regard the existing commercial differences as mere questions of policy about which each nation has mutual right to pursue its own interest, without of com plaint The Canadas, from their situation, are se- cure from all enemies but the United States. The defence and ornaments, therefore, for these prov inces must be designed to Keep this country in o- beyanee. The troops on their way to Canada with the forces already there, outnumber the whole reg uar army of the United States. But these things are only entitled to passing remark. We are all ways prepared for the contingencies incident to all governments. No nation is more desrous of cultiva ting the arts of peace, more capable of sustaining the shocks of war.---ROchester paper.

 Disastrous effects ef the iate Gale on the Lakes- The gale the destructive effects of which at Buffalo and on Lake Erie have been already described. Mon-

 real Courant of the 27th u speaks of it as one of the most disastrous gales which have visited the upper rivers within its recollection. The loss in lives and property is truly lamentable gives the following particulars :---

 The accounts of disasters on lake St. Peters are very distressing, and 1t is impossible say what ex- tent of damage has been done Fourteen rafts it is believed have been shattered and by some accounts the number of lives lost is estimated be nearly an hundred. We have spoken (says the Courant) with

 person who was one of those saved from a raft that was wrecked opposite to Pointe du Lac, on which there were B hands altogether, II of whom were drowned he described the suerings of the survivors as painful in the extreme. Eleven persons were res cued by the jollyboat of the Waterloo but the crow of the boat were unable to gain the Waterloo after they had taken up the sufferers, and it was feared they were lost; but happily when the Waterloo next morning stopped at Three Rivers they found that the jollyboat had reached that place, and that all was safe. The Waterloo we understand, sustained some inury in nearing the sufferers, by floating pieces of rafts 1; she also, when Quebec, struck on rock, by which she was damaged in the bottom but not so as to prevent her running for any length of time. Bateaux loaded with flower. &c. were also wrecked during the gale; and have been told that on the following morning the lake literally cov- cred with pieces of ras -four barrels wreck of bat teaux c. and presented vast of desolaton. In the course of the night of the wrecks passed Three Rivers, upon which several persons were cling ing, crying for assistance in the most appalling man. ner but from the extreme darknes of the night and the violence with which the tempest ragged it would have been impossible for the inhabitance of Three Rivers to render them any assistance-the attempt would have been attended with almost certain destruc- ton. The steamboat Lauzon, which plies between Point Levi and Quebec, in attempting to cross on Saturday morning with number of passengers, was carried by the violence of the gale below the falls of MOntmorenci---she reached Ouehec late in tho eva.

No article of Houshold Manufactures will be enti- tied to premium. unless manufactured entirely within the county

 To entitle himself to premiums for Agricultural Productions, the person claiming must state in wr- ting, and prove to the satisfaction of the Awarding Committee, the quantity of land and the amount of the product, Ito be ascertaned by measure, and must also state in writing the nature or kind of so-the previous situation of the iand-how tilled-the kind and quality ofmanure ,and how, and when appled--how the seed was applied, and how, and when sown, and the quantity per acre.

 The claims for premiums under this article must be entered with the Treasurer, MR. LEONARD Coop WIN before the 9th day of October next but the evidence of actual product except flax, which will be Wheat to the lst day of January, 1899 will be admit ted any time previous tho 1s day of January

 Persons intending to offer Domestic Animals, or ioushod manufactures, must give notice to the Treas arer, or before the 9th day of October next, re- questing an entry to be made of such notice.

 No premium will be awarded upon any erticc with competition unless such article shall be, in the pinion of the Awarding Committee, highly merito- rious. ~E-e

 No Animal or article of Houshold Manufacture, which shall have obtained premium at a previous ex- hibition, will, under the same denomination be enti- tied to a second premium.

 en by, and of the butter made from, the Mlch Cows entered for premiums, credbly aitested will be requi- red by the Awarding Committe.

 The examination of Domestic Animals and Hous- hold Manufactures will commence near the Court House, at g A. M. |..

 No person but a member of the Society, can be en- titled to premium except on Hearth Rugs, Bonnets, Stockings and other articles of Domestic Manufac- lures highly meritorious. ss

 All premiums not called for within three months af ter awarded, will be forfeited to the Society.

 UAll persons in arrears to the Society, are rec questcd to forward the amount to the Treasurer.

Modesty seems to have deserted republics, and taken refuge in courts. Such sent ment as this from Gen. Jackson would have rendered him irnmortal--but he seems better disposed to act on the maxim, "to keep what he gets, and get what he can''---[R Rich. Whig.1

full articles.article:
At General Assembly of the State of Connecticut,

 holden at Hartford in tke said State, on the first

 "Wednesday of May, in the year of our Lord one

 ttousand eight hundred aud tsoenty-secen.

 RESOLVED, By the House ef Representations, That the following be proposed as amendments to the Con- sttution of this State. which, when approvedsand a. dopted in the manner by the Constitution prescribed, shato all ntents and purposes, become part thereof

 Art. lst, From and after the first Wednesday of red and thirty, the Senate of this State shall consist of no less than eighteen no more than twenty-four members, to be chosen by Districts.

 Art. 2d The General Assembly which shall be hol- den on the hast Wednesday of May, in the year one the State into districts for the choice of Senator's and shall determine what number shall be elected in each which districts shall not be less than eight more than tweuty-our in number, and shall always be com- posed of contiguous territory, and in forming them no town shall be divided shall the whole Or part of one county be joined to the whole or part of another county, to form district; regard being had to the population in said apportionment and in forming said districts in such manner that county shall have less than two Senators. The districts, when established, shall continue the until the session of the Gem eral Assembly next after the completion of the next cencns of the United States; which said Assembly shall have power to alter the same, if found necessary preserve proper equality between said districts in respect to the number of inhabitants theren accord

 ing to the principles above recited; after which said

 

 tors altered, except any session of the General As. sembly next after the completion of census of the United States and then only according to the princ. pies above described. VI #essT1 AIM s5

 Art. Sd At the meeting of Electors on the first Mon day of April, in the year one thousand eight hundred and thirty, and annually thereafter immediately after the choice of Representatives the Electors qualified by law to vote in the choice of such Representatives shall be called upon, by the presiding officer in sucL meeting, in the several towns within their districts spectivey bring in their ballots for such person or

 number of persons, to be Senator Senators for suc Districts in the next General Assembly, as shall by law be allowed to such Districts respectively: which person or persons, the time of holding such meet. ngs shall belong to- and reside in the respective Die. tric,s in which they shall be so balloed for as afcre- saidAnd each Elector present at such meeting qua- flied aforesaid may thereupon bring in his ballot or suffrage for such person persons he shall choose be Senators for such Districts, not exceeding the number by law allowed to the same, with the name names of such person persons faisy written on one piece of paper.And the votes so given in shalt be received counted, canyassed and declared in the same manner provided by the Constitution for the choice ofsenatcrs-T The person or persons (nct ex- ceedng the number by law allowed to the Districts in which such vote shall be given in) having the highest number Of y0es shall be declared to be duly elected for such Dstric.s-But in the event of equality of votes between two or more of the persons voted tors vidcd for by the Committe, designate which of such persons shall be declared to hs duly elected.  CHriosities o Kep.--At Kew, there is neither doc tor lawyer, nor barber; the postmaster, it is said, neither read write and it IS vcarage with out vicar, he having made himself conspicuous at Thurtes trial has ever since been absent; yet there is no lack of Sermons, for the Inkeepers bear ing that name, and his brother, butcher, have each a large family ..

 Extraordinary Weather.---The thermometer which, Thursday and Friday last, ranging from so to 84 gradually sunk down to 60 on Friday night, after a thunder gust and heavy fall ofrain. We experienced on Saturday morning such an Atmosphere as usually accompanies September dawn, the wind East and North, and varying once twice to the West. It is still very cool and we find warm covering very agree able.--1 Charleston Paper, June 25.1

full articles.headline: FOR THE COUNTY POST.
full articles.article:
MR. EDrToR---Fate has so ordered it. together with my own folly that should belong to that much scof fed at and think I can truly and understndingly say from experience, miserable class of bipeds, ycleped "Old Bachelors.'' Now I should like to trouble the younger part of your readers with few words upon this subject. I shall not tire their pa- tience with long recital of the kicks and cuffs which have received, nor the mseries which have endl- red in consequence of remaining in "state of sim gle blesseduess, as it is called. When was young although Twas souckya chap toinitiae myself into the goodgraces of the ladies' took for my text

 It's not good for man take himself wife,, and many is the good practical discourse which, have preached therefrom, to my young companions-tho' not with remarkably good success. But stuck per tinaciously and obsnatey to it, albe until subse- quenty began to think that my preaching had para

 Tel in that ofa certain pious monk, whogpreached long sermon against stealing and its pernicons and mischevous effects, while at the same time he had pudding in his sleeve which he had obtained by theft

 would inform them at the present time, that have experienced good deal of misery sitting and lisen- ing the " solitary sghings my tea-ketle" long as have done ---and thai Ihave no notion of making virtue of necessity in extolling the happiness of a bachelors lfeit is but of dogs life the best ---and would recommend to every one to Keep clear of it. the wise and cogent arguments of Peter Single to the contrary notwithstanding. To tell the plain truth, although the miseres have euudergone moi quite equal those of the fabed Tyus. who is rep- resented in Eneas' descent into Hades, as having a ravenous vuture digging into his side and devouring his iver which grows fast enough to satisfy the yora- cious appetite of the bird yet they of ordinary nature. isan erroneous opinion which some young people have, of the danger of being wrecked upon the shoals of matrimony, ifthey sail that cruise ;but they may rest assured the authority of one whose knowledge has been dervedfom experience, ,thatthey will eventually sink in the qucksands and ouagmires of single bessedness, fthes travel that road. Let some your young readers, who halting between opinions just fancy to themselves an oldsuperan- nuated bachelor, the very picture of loneliness like myself for nstance sitting in his corner with pair ofspectacles athwart his asaprotuberance, poringo verthe pages of" The Bachelor" (which you maybe assured does not afford him much consolatio---or s- tening the aforementioned music of the tea-kettle ruminating on by-gone days and come to their own couclusions. Although never expect to tako to my self ri6, being too old to think of such step now earnestly advise all my brother bachelors each to obtain for himself cae sponsa as soon as may be.-- And would advise the young men, in the favourite language of Peter Single, to avoid being a bache lor" avoid it as you would the devil.''

 se & AN OLD BACHELOR.

SEC. l. Be H enacted by the Senate and HoussTof Representatives 0s General Assembly cOmrened That m all cases where loans of money have been made3n by tine Bank of the United States or bys thes Branch thereof located in this state, by any incorporated institutions in this stae wherein the rate ofnteresthas been calculated according to the standard laid down declared to be valid, all intens and purposes Pro vided that in all other respects, the laws of this State shall have been complled with therein.

 SEC :. And6 further enacted, That no Court of law within this state shall entertain admit any plea of usury to bar any claim due to any Bank ncorpora ted by the legislature of this State any ndivdu al when the rate of interest charged by such Bank or by such ndividual has been calculated or deduct ed according to the interest tables of Rowlett.

The frss Ecrlesias.ioal Church and Society in this town have, with the most perfect unanimity, voted CaltO Rev. Daniel L. Carol, of Aeghany Co. Penn. late of the Theological Seminary, PrincesOn, N. T. become their spiritual teacher and guide, in the gOs pei ministry. The perfect harmony which prevailed in the Church aud Society in voting this invitation, and in offering support of $IOOO per annun, induces hope that Mir. c. will accept the call, and soon be settled among

 The Students of the Law Office, in this village, eel ebrated the fy-frst anniversary of American Inde- pendence, by appropriate exercises in St. Michaels Church, and public dinner. The address by Mir. Parker heard with interest and pleasure by all in the house. His few remarks inrelaon to present na- tional poltcswere such might have been expected from liberal and enlightened mind He made no aIuson to either of the candidates for the next Pres dency, personality but simply spoke of the principle So much agtated at the present day relative to state rights, and the Pretended encroachment upon these rights by the General Government; and showed most conclusiveIy that as nation, we have more to fear from the independent sovereignty of the individual states, than we have fromany liability encreachment

  ernment. This question is afavorite hobby with the opposition, who continually clamouring for the independence of the separate states and pretending lest this independence should be destroyed by the present administration. We care however, much inclined believe in the vulgar proverb that if the states are all claim the independence that Geor gia has recently claimed, there is much more danger that the "pigs will eat the sow, than there is that the SOW will eat up the pigs"

 After the close of the services at the Church, pro- cession was formed by the Students, accompanied by several respectable gentlemen of the village, which moved to the County House, where dinner was ser- we'd up; after partaking of which the following toasts were drank:-

 1. The Day we ceebrate-Glorious as the natal of Our country--great in the annals of Freedomlong 1t continue to be celebrated Jubilee by her sous. -3 cheers

 2. Our Country-The chosen home ofthe free-the refuge of the oppressed-May day arrive when the cank of saverys chain shall be no longer heard and her foot not find resting place upon our so--- s cheers.

 3. The Constitution of the United States-Wisdom and Prudence presided at its formaton--may it's de- crees be enforced with Justice and moderation ---3 cheers. .

 4. The memory ofWashington.- Drank 6a silence.

 ,. The President of the United States & Heads of Departments.---3 Cheers. g4y

 6. Tho Governor of Connecticut.-.-3Cheers

 '. The late Governor of Connecticut the eve- ming of his life be calm its morn was brilliant ---6 Cheers. 8. The surviving Heroes of the Revolution----the few remaining monuments of glorious age--to them are we indebted for the rich inheritance enjoy and sooB may the Justice of an enfarehised people smoothe their passage to the grave, by rescung them from the cold embrace of Penury.--6 Cheers

 9. The Army---In the hour of danger and of peril it has noby discharged its duty, in peace let us cherish it.---3 Cheers #

 10. The Navy---In War our bulwark, in Peace our pride----nay its glory increase with its strength--3 Cheers.

 II. Charles Carroll-.--Tbe sole surviving signer of that instrument which pucked the brightest gem from Brtans glitterng coronal and gave existence na- ton ;brliany shone his rising gloriousy beam his setting sun.--6 Cheers

 12. Our Liberty---An ollodidl eState won by the sword, and held by in fee simple, may descend to prosteriy free from rack rent, and unncumbered by burdensome mortguges.---6 Cheers.

 l3. The Fair

 What despots in the battle field

 Have tried to do in van---

 To make the free unto them yield

 And wear a chain-

 The far--.the cruel fair have done

 They've done it by their winsome wiles

 What arms could not, their witchery,s won--

 What magic's In their smiles.-.- Cheers.

 IA number of volunteer Toasts were drank but we are obliged to omit them for want of room.l

 On the Eth ult. very large and respectable meeting of wool growers manufacturers and others interested in the promotion of American industry, convened at Rutland Vt. for the purpose of considering the expe- diency of Appointing delegatesto the Haisburgh Con- vention. Many able addresses were made to the meet ing in support of sundry resolutions approving the pursued by the great and patriotic state of Pennsylvania, in calling convention at this time, in order to take firm and enlightened stand in favor of the American System. Mr. Mallary, the able chairman of the Committee Manufactures, in the last Con- gress, addressed the meeting, and urged the import ance of the appointment of delegates to the Penn. meeting, for the purpose of refutng in the clearest manner the oft repeated assertion upon the floor of Congress, that the American farmer has no interest in the protection of manufactures, and is totally inder- ent to the success of the Woollens Bl-the measure having originated entirely in the avarice of rich cap- taists. Theremarks of Mir. M. in support of the ap- Pointment ofdelegates from Vt. will apply with equal force to Connecticut But we presume few if any of agricultural readers require argumentsto to convince them of the importance of protecting and encouraging domestic industry. At the above meeting the follow ing gentlemen were appointed delegates to the Harris hurgh Convention: Wm. Jarvis Esq. Hon. R. c. Malary, Hon. Elijah Paine, Wm. Hall, Esq. and Hon. Heman Allen.

 About Seventy delegates assembled ai HarrishuEgh Pa. on the e7th ult from the different counties in tai state, for the purpose of appointing delegates to the General Convention which is to meet at that place on the Both inst consider the present state of our wool growing .aDd wool manufacturing interest, and such other manufactures require encouragement. The following the organization of the meeting, and IS also list of the delegates to the general convention. ConrentiOa at Hnrisburg---Judge Burnside was President and Jas. $. Graft, Secretary. The follow ing is a correct list of the Delegates appointed in the general convention; Hon. John Todd of Bedford, Charles Ingersoll, of Philadelphia, Matthew Carey, of Philadelphia, Hon. Charles Huston, of Centre, Hon. Waiter Forward, of Pittsburg, Hon. Jonathan Roberts, of Montgomery, Joseph Patterson, Esq. of Pittsburg, Hon. Joseph Ritner, of Washington, Jas Todd, of Fayere, Wm. Clark, of Cauphin, David Townsend, of Chester, Samuel Baird, of Berks, Wm P. Macay, of Miflin Alexander Reed of Washing ton, Daniel Montgomery, ofColumbia. and Geo. Den- nisOn of Luzerne. "aa

 Public opinion is fast developing itself. From the Eastfrom the West, and from the North, the news IS most cheering. The violent hostility of the leaders of the opposition to Domestic industry protected by the Wooen B--the defeat of the hundred and SSrty thOusGd dOlLGrS interest saving bilthe violent and indscrminate opposition to the Administration, right wrong, and the bitter personal denunciaon of the i members of the Government who have grown old in the faithful performances of public servce are, bihed producing strong reaetlon and the People are railyng with firm and cheerful spirit in defence of the Government of their country.--- VttGge Record. The Duke of Wellington acknowledged in the House of Lords that it would be ridiculous in him to think himself qualified to act Prime Minister of England, thongh he thought himself qualified to com mand her armies. Modesty seems to have deserted republics, and taken refuge in courts Such senti- l T.aI him mmorta--but he seems better disposed to act on 1 the maxim, "to keep what he gets and get what he can''-[ Rich. Whg.1

 The following paragraph is copied from the Mon 1 treal Courant of Wednesday last;

 "The Hon. Col. J. Ramsay, brother of His Excel lency the Governor in Chief has lately arrived with despatches to His Excellency from England. We un- derstand that immediately upon his reaching the Gov ernor messenger was sent to summon the attendance of the Socito~ General, and the whole party to 1 proceed forthwith to Quebec, to examine the de- spatches. It Is rumored, but we give it only that the despaches contain instructions of HiSEx. to take away the constitution hitherto enjoyed by the country and to place 1t under the control of the Gov ernor and Council; which measure, 1t is said, was occasioned by the difficulties which constantly distract the Provincial Parliament. It is not very probable that this report correct for the constitution was ] granted to this country by act of Parliament we presume it could onysbe taken away by one, unless 1 there was provision in the act by which 1t was | try it might be taken away. Certain it is that the | despatches contain something of importance to the country, and probably will put rest to the exist ing difficulties, which we should not regret. It is certain that strong military force is coming out to this country, for what purpose we cannot dvine." Military naoremepts.--The embarkation of British troops for Canada, the enrolment and discipline of the provincial militia, and the extensive fortifcations now going forward wears an appearance of hostile preparations, according better with times that have l passed than the amcable relations which now ex- ist between England and America. We regard the existing commercial differences as mere questions of policy about which each nation has mutual right to pursue its own interest, without of com plaint The Canadas, from their situation, are se- cure from all enemies but the United States. The defence and ornaments, therefore, for these prov inces must be designed to Keep this country in o- beyanee. The troops on their way to Canada with the forces already there, outnumber the whole reg uar army of the United States. But these things are only entitled to passing remark. We are all ways prepared for the contingencies incident to all governments. No nation is more desrous of cultiva ting the arts of peace, more capable of sustaining the shocks of war.---ROchester paper.

 Disastrous effects ef the iate Gale on the Lakes- The gale the destructive effects of which at Buffalo and on Lake Erie have been already described. Mon-

 real Courant of the 27th u speaks of it as one of the most disastrous gales which have visited the upper rivers within its recollection. The loss in lives and property is truly lamentable gives the following particulars :---

 The accounts of disasters on lake St. Peters are very distressing, and 1t is impossible say what ex- tent of damage has been done Fourteen rafts it is believed have been shattered and by some accounts the number of lives lost is estimated be nearly an hundred. We have spoken (says the Courant) with

 person who was one of those saved from a raft that was wrecked opposite to Pointe du Lac, on which there were B hands altogether, II of whom were drowned he described the suerings of the survivors as painful in the extreme. Eleven persons were res cued by the jollyboat of the Waterloo but the crow of the boat were unable to gain the Waterloo after they had taken up the sufferers, and it was feared they were lost; but happily when the Waterloo next morning stopped at Three Rivers they found that the jollyboat had reached that place, and that all was safe. The Waterloo we understand, sustained some inury in nearing the sufferers, by floating pieces of rafts 1; she also, when Quebec, struck on rock, by which she was damaged in the bottom but not so as to prevent her running for any length of time. Bateaux loaded with flower. &c. were also wrecked during the gale; and have been told that on the following morning the lake literally cov- cred with pieces of ras -four barrels wreck of bat teaux c. and presented vast of desolaton. In the course of the night of the wrecks passed Three Rivers, upon which several persons were cling ing, crying for assistance in the most appalling man. ner but from the extreme darknes of the night and the violence with which the tempest ragged it would have been impossible for the inhabitance of Three Rivers to render them any assistance-the attempt would have been attended with almost certain destruc- ton. The steamboat Lauzon, which plies between Point Levi and Quebec, in attempting to cross on Saturday morning with number of passengers, was carried by the violence of the gale below the falls of MOntmorenci---she reached Ouehec late in tho eva.

No article of Houshold Manufactures will be enti- tied to premium. unless manufactured entirely within the county

 To entitle himself to premiums for Agricultural Productions, the person claiming must state in wr- ting, and prove to the satisfaction of the Awarding Committee, the quantity of land and the amount of the product, Ito be ascertaned by measure, and must also state in writing the nature or kind of so-the previous situation of the iand-how tilled-the kind and quality ofmanure ,and how, and when appled--how the seed was applied, and how, and when sown, and the quantity per acre.

 The claims for premiums under this article must be entered with the Treasurer, MR. LEONARD Coop WIN before the 9th day of October next but the evidence of actual product except flax, which will be Wheat to the lst day of January, 1899 will be admit ted any time previous tho 1s day of January

 Persons intending to offer Domestic Animals, or ioushod manufactures, must give notice to the Treas arer, or before the 9th day of October next, re- questing an entry to be made of such notice.

 No premium will be awarded upon any erticc with competition unless such article shall be, in the pinion of the Awarding Committee, highly merito- rious. ~E-e

 No Animal or article of Houshold Manufacture, which shall have obtained premium at a previous ex- hibition, will, under the same denomination be enti- tied to a second premium.

 en by, and of the butter made from, the Mlch Cows entered for premiums, credbly aitested will be requi- red by the Awarding Committe.

 The examination of Domestic Animals and Hous- hold Manufactures will commence near the Court House, at g A. M. |..

 No person but a member of the Society, can be en- titled to premium except on Hearth Rugs, Bonnets, Stockings and other articles of Domestic Manufac- lures highly meritorious. ss

 All premiums not called for within three months af ter awarded, will be forfeited to the Society.

 UAll persons in arrears to the Society, are rec questcd to forward the amount to the Treasurer.

 GT An ORATION will be delivered on the oc- casion. E$M

 Per order, s. P. BoLLEs, Rec. Sec.

 LTTCHFIELD, JUNE 21, 1897.

Be I enacted by the Senate and House of Representations tn General Assembly coa e,ed, That the town of Mansfield, in Windham Coun,, he and thesame is hereby annexed to the county ofTolIand- Provided nevertheless, That all suits law and cuu- y, already commenced and pending, or which may be commenced before the rising of this Assembly where- in all any of the inhabitants of said town of Mans ield or either of them parties concerned shall proceed to final judgment and execution in the same manner as though this Act had not been passed-And said town of Mansfield shall pay according to the list ofsad town, it's part of all debts now existing against the County of Windham.

The fra Ecclesias,ical Church and Society in this town have, with the most perfect unanimy, voted a callsO Rev. Daniel L. Carol, of Aeghany Co. Penn. late of the Theological Seminary, Princeton, N ]. to become their spiritual teacher and guide, in the gOs pei ministry. The perfect harmony which prevailed in the Church aud Society in voting this invitation, and in offering support of sIOOO per annun, induces us to hope that Mr. c. will accept the cal and soon be settled among us.

Public opinion is fast developing itself. From the East---omthe West, and from the North, the is most cheering The violent hostility of the leaders of the opposition to Domestic industry as protected by the WoolIen BlI-he defeat of the hundred aud siry hOuS0nd dOLGrs' interest saving billhe violent and ndiscriminate opposition to the Administration, right or wrong and the bitter personal denunciaton of the members of the Government who have grown old in the faithful performances of public service, are, bihed producing strong reaction, and the People are raying with firm and cheerful spirit in defence oi the Government of their country. Village Record

The Duke of Wellington acknowledged in the House of Lords, that it would be- ridiculous in him to think himself qualified to act as Prime Minister o England, though he thought himself qualified to com mand her armies. Modesty seems to have deserted republics, and taken refuge in courts. Such sent ment as this from Gen. Jackson would have rendered him irnmortal--but he seems better disposed to act on the maxim, "to keep what he gets, and get what he can''---[R Rich. Whig.1
